issues.description: The problem statement's UML specifies Stock.findStockIngredient(String): StockIngredient (and the solution implements a single-argument findStockIngredient). The template, however, declares findStockIngredient(String name, boolean caseSensitive) only. This signature mismatch means students following the UML/problem or the solution will expect a one-argument method but the template's API differs, causing confusion and compilation/signature errors when they try to call findStockIngredient(name).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template Stock API match the problem UML and the solution by providing a single-argument method: public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name). Either change the existing two-argument method signature to the one-argument version or add a one-argument overload that delegates to the two-argument variant (e.g., findStockIngredient(String name) -> return findStockIngredient(name, true) or use case-sensitive lookup). This will align template, problem description, and solution signatures.

issues.description: Within the template Stock class there is an internal contradiction: add(String) and take(String) call findStockIngredient(String) (single-arg), but the template only defines findStockIngredient(String, boolean). This unintentional mismatch inside the template prevents the class from compiling and confuses students about which API to use.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the template's internal calls or method declaration. E.g., add a one-argument overload public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name) that delegates to the existing two-argument method (or change the existing declaration to the one-argument version). Ensure all calls inside Stock (add, take) and example uses (Main) consistently use the same signature.

issues.description: The problem statement and the solution expect a Stock.findStockIngredient method with a single String parameter (findStockIngredient(String)), but the template's Stock class defines findStockIngredient(String name, boolean caseSensitive). This mismatched signature (extra boolean parameter) breaks the straightforward mapping from the problem description to the provided template API and to the reference implementation. Students reading the problem will look for and try to call findStockIngredient(name) as described, but the template requires a different call shape; this may cause compilation confusion or extra cognitive load as students try to reconcile the APIs.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template API with the problem statement and solution by providing a single-parameter method. Either change the template method signature to public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name) (and implement the intended matching logic), or add an overload public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name) that delegates to the existing two-parameter variant with a sensible default for case sensitivity. This makes the method name and usage consistent across problem, template, and solution.
